meta.title: World 3: Control Flow - Lessons
meta.intro: In this world, you’ll learn how to control the flow of your Python programs using conditions (if/else) and loops (for, while).

lessons.title: if and else
lessons.html:
if statements let Python choose actions based on conditions. You can also add else for the opposite case.

age = 18
if age >= 18:
    print("Adult")
else:
    print("Minor")

Explanation: If the condition is true, Python runs the indented code. Otherwise, it goes to else.

Analogy: It’s like a traffic guard: if the light is green, cars go; else, they stop.

lessons.title: elif (else if)
lessons.html:
elif lets you check multiple conditions in order.

x = 0
if x > 0:
    print("Positive")
elif x == 0:
    print("Zero")
else:
    print("Negative")

Explanation: Python checks each condition top to bottom. The first true one runs, and the rest are skipped.

lessons.title: for loop
lessons.html:
for loops repeat code for a sequence or range.

for i in range(3):
    print(i)

Output: 0, 1, 2

Analogy: Imagine counting chairs in a row. The loop goes through each one.

lessons.title: while loop
lessons.html:
while repeats until the condition becomes false.

x = 0
while x < 3:
    print(x)
    x += 1

Explanation: As long as x < 3, the loop runs. Don’t forget to update variables, or it will loop forever!

lessons.title: break and continue
lessons.html:
break stops a loop completely. continue skips the rest of the current loop and jumps to the next.

for i in range(5):
    if i == 3:
        break
    print(i)

for j in range(5):
    if j == 2:
        continue
    print(j)

Output: First loop prints 0,1,2. Second loop prints 0,1,3,4 (skips 2).
